Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CyberSEES:Type 2: Framework to Advance Climate, Economics, and Impact Investigations with Information Technology (FACE-IT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Issues relating to climate change and food security require an understanding of the interaction between the natural world and human society over long time scales. Understanding climate change, its impacts on the natural world and society, and the tradeoffs inherent in societal responses demands an unprecedented degree of cooperation across academic fields. New data sources on expected future climate, soil characteristics, economic activity, historical weather, population, and land cover, provide a potential basis for this cooperation. New methods are needed for sharing within and across communities not only data but the software used to generate, synthesize, and analyze it. Progress on these research challenges is hindered by the extreme difficulties that researchers, collaborators and the community experience when they collaborate around data. Multiplicity of data formats, inadequate computational tools, difficulty in sharing data and programs, lack of incentives for pro-social behavior, and large data volumes are among the technology barriers. The FACE-IT project employs an integrated approach to cyberinfrastructure to advance the characterization of vulnerabilities, impacts, mitigation, and adaptation to climate change in human and environmental systems. Leveraging existing research cyberinfrastructure the project will create a full-featured FACE-IT Platform prototype with new capabilities for ingesting, organizing, managing, analyzing and using large quantities of diverse data. The project team will collaborate with two distinct interdisciplinary communities to create specific FACE-IT Instances that will both advance their research and enable at-scale evaluation of the utility of the FACE-IT approach.

Many important and challenging problems facing humankind occur at the intersection of the social, physical, biological, and computational sciences. The proposed methods and approaches have general applicability for advancing the use of research information across diverse communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change is a scientific topic too complex to fit into any single research discipline. Understanding the Earth’s climate and its effects on human society requires expertise and information from geophysical sciences, agriculture, economics, sociology, biology, and many other disciplines. However, there are many challenges in combining and working with data across these disparate fields, including incompatible data formats, inadequate computational tools for data analysis and visualization, large data volumes that are difficult to share or analyze, and cultural and technical obstacles to efficient collaboration.

FACE-IT (faceit-portal.org), a project jointly led by the Center for Robust Decision-making on Climate and Energy Policy (RDCEP, rdcep.org) at the University of Chicago and the Agricultural & Biological Engineering Department at the University of Florida, is a new IT infrastructure designed to remove these barriers and facilitate interdisciplinary research on climate change and its global impacts. The FACE-IT platform provides accessible, web-based tools for researchers to ingest, organize, manage, analyze and share large quantities of data from diverse origins, including social, physical, and biological sciences. Users can easily access and combine data such as climate model output, soil characteristics, economic activity and historical weather, and use it with software tools and high-performance cloud-computing resources for complex tasks such as simulation, analysis, and visualization. By facilitating ensemble simulations of multiple future scenarios for climate, agricultural production technologies and socio-economic pathways, FACE-IT facilitates researchers more efficiently assess the impacts of climate change on food security, poverty, and other key areas in order to provide stakeholders and policymakers with viable adaptation strategies.

The FACE-IT platform not only enables data and software sharing among scientists in developed countries, but especially improves access to these resources in the developing world, where climate change impacts are less well studied due to limited computational resources. Working with the tools developed by the Agricultural Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP, agmip.org), researchers in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia ran state-of-the-art analysis and modeling workflows using high-performance computing resources to better understand local climate risks and vulnerabilities in food supply, agriculture, and economics. Each simulation campaign representing a single cropping system in a region, required several million simulations, using different combinations of weather and management inputs. While it is possible to perform these simulations on a desktop computer, the FACE-IT workflow-building package enabled researchers to streamline the process, leaving more time for analysis of outputs.The FACE-IT platform can also be expanded for creating and sharing education and outreach modules that expose students around the world to cutting-edge climate and data science methods.
